| Section8 = {{Chembox Related OtherCpds = trisulfur SO, Ozone, SO 2
  }} }} 'Disulfur monoxide' or 'sulfur suboxide' is an unstable gas being a
  compound of sulfur and oxygen with formula S 2O. It is one of the
  lower sulfur oxides. It is a colourless gas. It can be formed by reacting
  thionyl chloride with silver sulfide:

:SOCl 2 + Ag 2S â AgCl + S 2O.

This is done under low pressure and high temperature. Another way to
form it is via a glow discharge in sulfur dioxide. The
arrangement of atoms is SSO in a bent form. The angle formed at the central
sulfur atom is 117.88Â°. The sulfur to sulfur bond length is 188.4pm, and the
length of the oxygen bond is 146.5pm. {{cite journal
| quotes = | last =Meschi | first =D.J. | authorlink = | coauthors = Myers R.J.|
| date = | year = 1959| month = | title = The microwave spectrum, structure, and
| dipole moment of disulfur monoxide| journal = Journal of Molecular
| Spectroscopy| volume = 3| issue =1â6 | pages =405â416 | publisher = | doi =
| 10.1016/0022-2852(59)90036-0| url = |bibcode = 1959JMoSp...3..405M }} It
| can form an orange red condensate at liquid nitrogen temperatures. On
| decomposition at room temperature it forms SO 2 and polysulfur
| oxide.

It is the base oxide for thiosulfurous acid. The formal
oxidation state for sulfur is +1; sulfur plays two different roles in the
molecule, however.
